com.gf.core
Class Engine

java.lang.Object
  com.gf.core.Engine
All Implemented Interfaces:
ActionService, ConfigService, ContextService, DeployService
public class Engine
extends java.lang.Object
implements ActionService, DeployService, ConfigService, ContextService

Engine is the central class of "Green-forest Framework".
Use it for create object with Action-Handler API: 

 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.putHandler(SomeActonHandler.class);
 String result = engine.invoke(new SomeAction("some data"));
 
 SomeAction otherAction = new SomeAction("other data");
 engine.invoke(otherAction);
 String otherResult = otherAction.getOutput();

Author:
Evgeny Dolganov
See Also:
Action, Handler, Interceptor, Filter

invoke

public <I,O> O invoke(Action<I,O> action)
         throws InvocationException,
                ExceptionWrapper,
                java.lang.RuntimeException
Handle the Action object with this Engine.
Use Handler, Interceptor, Filter for this.

The order of processing:

  • Filters
  • Interceptors
  • Handler

Interceptors and Handlers can call subInvoke method.
In this case the order of processing:

  • Filters (was called only once)
  • Interceptors
    • Sub Interceptors
    • Sub Handler
  • Handler
    • Sub Interceptors
    • Sub Handler

Specified by:
invoke in interface ActionService
Returns:
Action output object.
Note: This return value is the equivalent of code action.getOutput() after the invoke method.
Throws:
InvocationException - Engine's processing exception
ExceptionWrapper - wrapper of non-runtime Exception from handler's body
java.lang.RuntimeException - runtime Exception from handler's body
See Also:
invokeUnwrap(Action), Action, Handler, Interceptor, Filter

invokeUnwrap

public <I,O> O invokeUnwrap(Action<I,O> action)
               throws InvocationException,
                      java.lang.Exception
This method is invoke(Action) analog with unwrap non-runtime exceptions.

Example: 

 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class ActionHandlerWithException extends Handler<SomeAction>{
 
   public void invoke(SomeAction action) throws Exception {
     //not-runtime exception
     throw new Exception("test expection");
   }
   
 }
 
 ...
 
 //use invokeUnwrap
 try {
   engine.invokeUnwrap(new SomeAction());
 }catch (Exception e) {
   System.out.println(e);
 }
 
 //use invoke
 engine.invoke(new SomeAction()); //throws ExceptionWrapper

Specified by:
invokeUnwrap in interface ActionService
Throws:
InvocationException
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
invoke(Action)

scanAndPut

public void scanAndPut(java.lang.String packageName)
                throws NoMappingAnnotationException,
                       NotOneHandlerException
Scan packages and put all handlers, interceptors, filters into this Engine.

Example: 

 //handler
 package some.package.subPackage;
 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class SomeHandler extends Handler<SomeAction>{...}
 
 //engine
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.scanAndPut("some.package");
 engine.invoke(new SomeAction());

Note: For some Application Servers (JBoss AS for example) you need to setup ReflectionsScanner. Or you can use your own ClassScanner.

Specified by:
scanAndPut in interface DeployService
Parameters:
packageName - root package for scan (example: "com.some.package")
Throws:
NoMappingAnnotationException
NotOneHandlerException
See Also:
ClassScanner, ClassScannerKey

                throws NoMappingAnnotationException,
                       NotOneHandlerException

Note: For some Application Servers (JBoss AS for example) you need to setup ReflectionsScanner. Or you can use your own ClassScanner.

setConfig

public <T> void setConfig(java.lang.Class<? extends ConfigKey<T>> keyType,
                          T value)
               throws EmptyClassException
Set config value by key type. You can create own config keys for using in handlers.
Example of using: 
 //key
 public class SomeConfigKey extends ConfigKey<String>{
 
   public boolean hasDefaultValue() {
     return true;
   }
   
   public String getDefaultValue() throws Exception {
     return "some default value";
   }
 }
 
 //handler
 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class SomeHandler extends Handler<SomeAction>{
 
   public void invoke(SomeAction action) throws Exception {
     String value = config.getConfig(new SomeConfigKey());
     log.info(value);
   }
 }
 
 //engine
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.putHandler(SomeHandler.class);
 engine.setConfig(SomeConfigKey.class, "some value");
 engine.invoke(new SomeAction());

Specified by:
setConfig in interface ConfigService
Parameters:
keyType - not null type
value - some value for this config type (can be null)
Throws:
EmptyClassException - if keyType is null
See Also:
ConfigKey

getConfig

public <T> T getConfig(ConfigKey<T> key)
            throws GetConfigValueException
Get config value or default value or exception if key doesn't have default value.
Example: 
 //key with default value
 public class SomeConfigKey extends ConfigKey<String>{
 
   public boolean hasDefaultValue() {
     return true;
   }
   
   public String getDefaultValue() throws Exception {
     return "some default value";
   }
 }
 
 //key without default value
 public class OtherConfigKey extends ConfigKey<String>{
 
   public boolean hasDefaultValue() {
     return false;
   }
 }
 
 //engine
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 
 String val1 = engine.getConfig(new SomeConfigKey());
 System.out.println(val1); //<--------- print "some default value"
     
 engine.setConfig(SomeConfigKey.class, "some value");
 String val2 = engine.getConfig(new SomeConfigKey());
 System.out.println(val2); //<--------- print "some value"
     
 engine.getConfig(new OtherConfigKey()); //<---------- get GetConfigValueException

Specified by:
getConfig in interface ConfigService
Throws:
GetConfigValueException
See Also:
ConfigKey

isTrueConfig

public boolean isTrueConfig(ConfigKey<java.lang.Boolean> key)
                     throws GetConfigValueException
Get boolean value of Boolean config key. If value is null return false. Anolog of getConfig(ConfigKey): Boolean.TRUE.equals(getConfig(key))

Specified by:
isTrueConfig in interface ConfigService
Throws:
GetConfigValueException
See Also:
ConfigKey

setConfigValues

public void setConfigValues(java.util.Properties props)
                     throws ParsePropertiesException
Parse config values from Properties. Key must be a config key's Class string.
For example: 
 //file config.properties
 some.package.SomeConfigKey=value 1
 some.package.OtherConfigKey=value 2
 com.gf.key.TraceHandlers=true 
 
 //props
 InputStream is = getResourceAsStream("config.properties");
 Properties props = new Properties();
 props.load(is);
 
 //engine
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.setConfigValues(props);
 String val1 = engine.getConfig(new SomeConfigKey());
 String val2 = engine.getConfig(new OtherConfigKey());
 boolean val3 = engine.isTrueConfig(new TraceHandlers());
 System.out.println(val1); //print "value 1"
 System.out.println(val2); //print "value 2"
 System.out.println(val3); //print "true"

Specified by:
setConfigValues in interface ConfigService
Throws:
ParsePropertiesException
See Also:
ConfigKey

addToContext

public void addToContext(java.lang.Object object)
Add some object to current engine context. So this object can be injected into filters, interceptors, handlers.

Example: 

 //engine
 SomeService someService = new SomeService();
 OtherService otherService = new OtherService();
 Engine engine = new Engine();
 engine.addToContext(someService);
 engine.addToContext(otherService);
 engine.putHandler(SomeHandler.class);
 engine.invoke(new SomeAction());
 
 //handler
 @Mapping(SomeAction.class)
 public class SomeHandler extends Handler<SomeAction>{
   
   @Inject
   SomeService service;
   
   @Inject
   OtherService otherService;
   
   @Override
   public void invoke(SomeAction action) throws Exception {
   
     service.someMethod();
     otherService.invoke(new OtherAction()); //it can be an another Engine. Why not?
     
   }
 }

Specified by:
addToContext in interface ContextService
See Also:
Inject
